title: 112_hr5910
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Investment in American Jobs Act of 2012". Congress finds that it is crucial to improve economic growth, create new jobs, and maintain an open investment climate for domestic prosperity and security. The United States has seen a decline in inbound global investment relative to its GDP, leading to increased competition for investment from other countries. Foreign direct investment from global companies benefits the US economy by providing jobs for millions of Americans with above-average compensation and strengthening the industrial base. Global companies investing in the US contribute significantly to the economy by employing 15% of the manufacturing sector workforce, generating 18% of exports, investing over $41 billion in research and development, paying 17% of corporate income taxes, and purchasing $1.8 trillion in domestic goods and services annually. These companies account for 5.8% of the US economy. The US economy is significantly impacted by global companies investing in the country, accounting for 5.8% of the private sector GDP. The government has prioritized increasing inbound global investment, with initiatives like the SelectUSA program and the National Investment Initiative aiming to attract significant foreign business investment. Initiative to attract $1 trillion in new business investment from abroad, US and EU unveil principles for open international investment to encourage open investment policies globally and open new markets for US companies. Sense of Congress. The sense of Congress is that attracting inbound investment is crucial for the long-term economic prosperity, competitiveness, and security of the United States. To maintain its attractiveness for global investment, Congress and federal agencies should consider the impact on foreign direct investment when evaluating legislation. Enhancing competitiveness and prosperity by removing barriers to global investment is a top national priority. The United States aims to remain a top destination for global companies to invest, hire, innovate, and manufacture products. Policies on foreign direct investment should prioritize national security interests. The Foreign Direct Investment and International Financial Data Improvements Act of 1990 is being amended. The Foreign Direct Investment and International Financial Data Improvements Act of 1990 is being amended to include a review of United States laws and policies on foreign direct investment. The Secretary of Commerce will lead an interagency review to develop recommendations for making the U.S. more competitive in attracting and retaining foreign investment. The review conducted pursuant to paragraph (1) includes assessing the economic impact of foreign direct investment in the United States, analyzing laws and policies affecting foreign investment, and evaluating the competitive position of the U.S. for attracting foreign companies. The review conducted under paragraph (1) includes assessing the economic impact of foreign direct investment in the United States, analyzing laws and policies affecting foreign investment, evaluating the competitive position of the U.S. for attracting foreign companies, ongoing Federal Government efforts to improve the investment climate, reduce investment barriers, facilitate greater levels of foreign direct investment, recommendations for making the U.S. more competitive in attracting global investment, the impact of foreign direct investment on innovation and national economic competitiveness, and a review of State and local government initiatives to attract foreign investment. The Secretary of Commerce shall include the results of the review in the first report prepared under subsection (a) of this section after the enactment of the Global Investment in American Jobs Act of 2012, with an open comment period for public input. The Global Investment in American Jobs Act of 2012 was passed by the House of Representatives on September 19, 2012. Karen L. Haas attested to this.
